posts.name: Javier Lopez
posts.cooked: Hi! I’m a newbie programmer from team 7088 that is starting from scratch this year. We just returned from our first regional event here in Texas and we wanted to attempt to auto balance during autonomous. I’ve been all over the FIRST webpage looking for examples but I really don’t know how to start using ay of the navX2 capabilities.

Our robot looked at pitch.  We moved onto the ramp and then switched to auto balancing.  We saw pitch values above 10 while climbing.  As soon as pitch went below 5 we stopped the robot.  If pitch flipped sign and went -10, we backed up.  Our robot didn’t exit the autobalance logic until pitch remained near 0 for several loops.

import com.kauailabs.navx.frc.AHRS; import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.SPI; //I connected using SPI

AHRS gyro = new AHRS(SPI.Port.kMXP);  //add as a global variable near the top

gyro.calibrate();  //calibrate in robot init

pitch =   gyro.getPitch();    //use in autonomous, create a double pitch

Hope this helps.  Good luck.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
It depends on how you have the Navx mounted (vertically, or horizontally).  Ours is vertical, so we’re going off the roll value.

Feel free to look at our code and use any of it you think can help. Our repo is public .

We succeeded just using two different BangBangControllers from WPILib, one for climbing up the ramp and one for backing up and correcting.

You’ll see a BangBang command in our repo, along with a Test version of that command that can be run from SmartDashboard (or Shuffleboard) for rapid iteration of the values.

link_counts.title: GitHub - Lambda-Corps/2023_ChargedUp: Public Repo for 1895's 2023 FRC competition season.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: I used the original NavX (which I have been told is exactly the same only less consistent). I used getPitch() and put it in a PIDController that would generate percent output values for our drivetrain motors. I used 0.0 for the I gain and a very small D. PIDController documentation which is surprisingly easy to implement.

link_counts.title: PID Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Javier Lopez
posts.cooked:
I tried creating a PID controller using the NAVx’s pitch but for some reason as I’m trying to set the motor controllers power to the PID output t is giving me an error. Also I am still confused as to what the setpoint value is supposed to correspond to. Screenshot 2023-03-15 124210 928×516 35.7 KB

Screenshot 2023-03-15 124210 928×516 35.7 KB

Screenshot 2023-03-15 124210 928×516 35.7 KB

posts.name: Drakxii
posts.cooked: You need the ControlMode.PercentOutput, as Set requires a ControlMode and a value.  Look at the drive commands in the first if statements.

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: This might not be a problem, but in my code I declare and define the PIDController at initialization. I don’t think it should be in periodic. Like your I and D values, the P value should be a constant that doesn’t change based on pitch. A setpoint is the measured value the controller is trying to achieve. Having it at zero like you do means it’s trying to drive the pitch to 0, which is correct.

Yes, pitch is only applicable if the RoboRio is flat.  Yaw or roll will be needed in other orientations.  I would just dump all 3 into a data file as you drive over the ramp and see which one is being used.

We just used very simple controls setting motor power commands to around  .1 on the way up, 0 if level, and -0.1 if it went too far.  We added a counter for 0 as if it goes to far you go through 0.  I think we count to 25 or something before exiting.

I’m a huge fan of PID but I don’t see it as very useful here, it’s overkill for this particular problem.  Not every nail needs the PID hammer.

posts.name: Javier Lopez
posts.cooked: If I do not declare the PID  controller in periodic it ends up not recognizing it and giving me an error. What would be recommended P, I and D values and how does each value affect the program altogether?

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked:
Here is how my team did it. As another commenter pointed out, PID might not be the hammer for this situation. However, it is my favorite hammer and I feel like it’s less complicated than people think. Firstly, this line

This is how I declare the controller. This goes at the beginning of the class outside of any methods. Near it, I would put constants for P I and D

These happen to be 1699’s. It would be best if you used them as a starting point and changed them later.

This next line should go in an “init” method, in robotInit() if you’re working in Robot.java

This will instantiate the controller. The other method you need to use (that you correctly used in your original code) is calculate(). You should run the method exactly the way you did by passing in the getPitch() value. If you’re spinning in circles or just driving in random directions:

the two sides of your robot will need to drive in opposite directions.

if you are driving backwards, they might both be reversed

And finally, if you need help with what PID is in the first place, I made these information slides a few months back that will let you know what all the values actually mean. https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1O49rLInOUlJf6whXiO50LtPr5JGgu1qAb0rdSoW4FP4/edit?usp=sharing
